_description: GDPR and ePrivacy Directive reference data for privacy analysis context. Key concepts, principles, and regulatory requirements relevant to cookie consent and tracking analysis.

gdpr.scope: Processing of personal data of EU/EEA residents

consent.description: The data subject has given consent to the processing of their personal data for one or more specific purposes.
requirements: Must be unambiguous indication (clear affirmative action)
Must be as easy to withdraw as to give
Pre-ticked boxes do NOT constitute valid consent
Silence or inactivity does NOT constitute consent
Cookie walls may undermine freely given consent

legitimate_interest.description: Processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or a third party, except where overridden by the interests or fundamental rights of the data subject.
requirements: Data subjects can object at any time
Cannot be used for profiling that produces legal effects
legitimate_interest.notes: TCF allows vendors to declare legitimate interest for certain purposes, but DPAs have frequently challenged this for advertising purposes.

contract.description: Processing is necessary for the performance of a contract.

legal_obligation.description: Processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation.

vital_interests.description: Processing is necessary to protect vital interests.

public_interest.description: Processing is necessary for a task carried out in the public interest.

key_principles.data_minimisation: Personal data must be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary.
key_principles.purpose_limitation: Data must be collected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes.
key_principles.storage_limitation: Data must not be kept longer than necessary for the purposes.
key_principles.transparency: Processing must be lawful, fair and transparent to the data subject.
key_principles.accountability: The controller must be able to demonstrate compliance.

data_subject_rights: Right to erasure / right to be forgotten (Art. 17)
Right not to be subject to automated decision-making (Art. 22)

eprivacy_directive.full_name: Directive on Privacy and Electronic Communications
eprivacy_directive.requirement: Storing information or gaining access to information stored in terminal equipment (cookies) requires prior informed consent, except for cookies strictly necessary for a service explicitly requested by the user.

strictly_necessary.description: Cookies essential for providing a service explicitly requested by the user.

functional.description: Cookies that enhance functionality but are not strictly necessary.

analytics.description: Cookies used to measure website performance and usage.
analytics.notes: Some DPAs allow analytics without consent if properly anonymised (e.g., CNIL exemption for Matomo).

advertising.description: Cookies used for targeted advertising and tracking across sites.

social_media.description: Cookies set by social media platforms embedded in the page.

tcf_overview.current_version: v2.2 (v2.3 launched April 2025, adoption deadline February 2026)
tcf_overview.description: An industry standard that enables publishers and their technology partners to communicate user consent choices in a standardised way.

tc_string.description: A Base64url-encoded binary string that encodes all consent and transparency information.

global_vendor_list.description: Canonical list of all registered TCF vendors with their declared purposes, features, cookie usage, and data retention.
global_vendor_list.update_frequency: Regularly updated as vendors register or update declarations

cmp_api.description: JavaScript API that CMPs must expose on the page for vendors to query consent status.

consent_management_platform.description: Software that displays consent notices and collects user preferences.
requirements: Must be registered with IAB Europe
Must support all TCF purposes and features

compliance_concerns: Pre-consent tracking: Loading tracking scripts before consent is obtained
Dark patterns: Making 'Accept All' prominently visible while hiding reject options
Consent walls: Requiring consent to access content (debated legality)
Legitimate interest misuse: Using legitimate interest for advertising purposes
Vendor count transparency: Not clearly disclosing the number of data recipients
Partner list accessibility: Making partner lists difficult to find or read
Consent string validity: TC String not accurately reflecting user choices
Re-consent frequency: Not re-asking consent when vendor list changes significantly

gpc.name: Global Privacy Control
gpc.description: Browser-level signal indicating user preference to opt out of sale/sharing of personal data.
gpc.legal_recognition: Recognised under CCPA/CPRA (California), and gaining recognition in other jurisdictions.

dnt.name: Do Not Track
dnt.description: Legacy browser signal requesting not to be tracked. Largely deprecated and not legally binding.
dnt.status: Deprecated by most browsers and not widely respected by sites.
